key_points: U.S. advance retail sales surged by 9.8% in March, outperforming Dow Jones estimates of a 6.1% gain.
The increase followed a 2.7% decline in February and represented the best month for retail since May 2020.
Stimulus checks from the American Rescue Plan Act largely credited for the spending boost.
First-time filings for unemployment insurance for the week ended April 10 fell to 576,000, the lowest since the early days of the Covid-19 pandemic.
The unemployment rate has decreased from a pandemic peak of 14.7% to its current 6%.
Spending was broad-based across sectors with significant gains in sporting goods, clothing, and the bar and restaurant industry.
Despite the stimulus-fueled spending, a larger portion of the checks is being saved compared to the first round of stimulus.
Inflationary pressures are becoming evident, with a notable year-over-year consumer price index rise of 2.6% in March.
Consumption growth is expected to continue rebounding rapidly in the second quarter.
The labor market shows signs of improvement, with a significant addition of 916,000 nonfarm payrolls in March.
spokespersons: Michael Pearce (Senior U.S. Economist, Capital Economics)
